description: Exactly what i was looking for! simple wonderful and Kool!
great to manage time and intergrates well with kde.
summary: Amazing a great clock for kde

description:
1. To add a world clock, there is no "add" button after you've found the clock you are looking for. You'd have to tick the box, close the app and relaunch it for the clock to be added.

2. Main clock is only analog and can't be changed to digital.

3. Added world clock is only digital and cannot be changed to analog. Why?

4. You can't edit any of the clocks, even though there is an "edit" button there, which only brings up a box that prompts you search for a clock. Shouldn't it show the clocks that already there to edit them? Isn't that what "edit" buttons do, edit existing things? 

5. There are no tones to choose from. You'd have to choose from system settings. Again, why?

I don't understand the design dicisions of this app. Overall, it is an OK app,and does the littel things I wanted it to do.
Thanks for making this cool app, devs! It looks really nice on both destop and mobile. Love the convergent ui!

Creating an alarm it created 2 identical.
could not find any alarms even though I have an alrm in my musci folder

Great app, allows me to set alarms. One thing I'd want in this app is waking the computer from sleep and playing the alarm sound.
I'm using Fedora 38 KDE Spin.
Fine, but in Debian 13 Trixie, I can't browse my folders for a custom ringtone.

Good app, and it will be better if it has some other features for the World Clocks tab:
- Rearranging world clocks in any order
- Changing clocks from analog to digital and vice versa
- More locations for clocks (e.g. Wellington, Rio de Janeiro,...)

I never thought something as simple as a clock app would annoy me so much, but it really does. Whenever it goes off, I'd reach over to turn it off, accidentally dismiss the notification, and have to kill it from the system monitor because I have no idea how to turn off the alarm if you dismiss the notification. The entire time, this ear-piercing, infernal beeping would play. Great way to wake up.
Really useful program for scheduling stuff for when I get off track. Only complaint is that they missed the opportunity to call it Klock

The add alarm buttons donot work and I am simply not able to use this app to manage alarms
Other than that the UI seems quite good, also how it adapts to the resolution for mobile phones and desktops is amazing but still not perfect, for eg., clicking and staying on the sidebar and moving the cursor up and down makes it almost like a touch movement and the app responds to it. The same happens with Discover "Installing apps menu". Focus on laptops/desktop space rather than trying to make the devices mobile friendly, there is already android for that, which is also open source, so simply focus on the linux desktop space.
Kudos for trying to make these apps like this contacts, email/calendar suite, definitely kontact has gotten older.
Atleast now focus on minimalism and security/simplicity and maintain the sleek design.
Thats it these are my suggestions 
all the best kDEVs

Just installed on Ubuntu 22.04.2 LTS and Timer and Alarms don't work =
'Please start kclockd in order to have timer functionality'...
Not sure how to do that.

I am an ex window user. I really don't want to learn every nick and cranny about the different apps. Some apps need to be fully package. If every app is for experts then say so. You know? Like you need to be experienced in starting up the "clock daemon"?

Like others have mentioned, the main feature I was looking for (timers) doesn't work out of the box. Says to start `kclockd` daemon with no instructions, but when I try to run it, bash says "did you mean command 'kclock'", which is this application.
248 MB download and it still requires you do install something like kclockd or whatever!?

Ne fonctionnne tout simplement pas.
Impossible de rajouter un minuteur.
Timer doesn't work =( Need kclockd... Use snap.
